utterances: In villages I would find half the children gone up to a certain year, and the other half with pox marks.
So I knew that an epidemic had occurred.
Dr. Moore knew what to do: vaccinate the population.
But how to get the vaccine to the people?
Because we didn't have refrigeration.
So I ordered smallpox vaccine from the States by air pouch.
It took lot of it until we got something viable.
When he finally got a batch that had survived the journey, he put it in his kerosene refrigerator while he tried to figure out what to do next.
The refrigerator was too big to take along, so how could he get the vaccine into the villages?
And the only think I could think of was to get a ball of twine, white string.
And to use that twine to transfer the live virus of the vaccine from one person to another.
Here's how it worked.
He enlisted some local boys, vaccinated them with the imported vaccine, and then had them travel with him to the distance villages.
When you vaccinate someone for smallpox, it forms a little harmless pox, a sore that would substitute for refrigerated vaccine.
We touched the twine to the boys' pustule, then we touched it to the arm of the next person coming up and pricked his arm so that he that would get the virus.
And it all worked out beautifully.
It's not that any of this work was without cultural conflicts.
First there was the problem of wives.
The Nepalese women all wanted to know how many wives Dr. Moore and Dr. Brooks had.
We said, well, one.
That's our practice in America.
Well, this wasn't true, according to their customs.
And any man who had wealth had - surely had more than one wife.
So they - older women later brought the younger women all dolled up in ribbons and cleanly washed and so forth and they tried to push them forward.
And I mean somehow I got rid of them the first night, but the next morning when we opened our clinic no one came.
We'd insulted the village.
So Dr. Moore turned to Shiva(ph), his Gurkha translator and friend, and asked what they should do.
Shiva said you might think its offensive, but tell them you're too good for them.
We just let them know that we might be eligible, but the people of this village were not of that standing or not quite high enough in class, and they accepted that.
Now, they didn't always believe us.
And for weeks afterward the older women would bring the younger ones by Dr. Moore's compound.
They didn't come to see me.
They came to see wife number one.
Because wife number one had to approve any additions to the family.
And she understood.
She entertained them with a record player, tea and cookies, and it all worked out and she would say no.
When Lily Shum was little, she hardly ever raised her hand.
The teacher would call on her, and this was usually her answer - yep, crickets.
Lily Shum dreaded that moment, and not because she didn't know the answer.
She was just quiet.
Years later, she became a teacher.
At school, she keeps an eye on silent kids like her.
Dr.
Moore's wife, Connie, died earlier this year.
They had been married 60 years.
George Moore spent more than 20 years in the public health service.
He later taught at the Medical College of Virginia and became the director of a district health department in eastern Virginia.
Today he lives in a comfortable home overlooking an inlet of the Chesapeake Bay.
The vista is about as far from that of Nepal as one can get.
But the two years he spent in the mountain kingdom were the most gratifying assignment he ever had.
We were the first people in the country.
We broke the ice.
We found friends.
We were able to do what we wanted to do.
And we did the things that basically were done in this country probably 100 years ago, which was so important for the beginning of this nation.
And Dr. Moore says that what made his work particularly satisfying was the unique way he was able to combine successful medicine with successful diplomacy.
I think what we did was perhaps unusual, because I've talked to other people who have served overseas, and unfortunately we have not always been successful.
The way to be successful, Dr. Moore says, is to be careful that when you're trying to solve other country's problems you don't interfere more than you have to.
Help the people, he says, but in their own way.

Kenneth Clark is best remembered as the psychologist and professor whose research into racial discrimination helped to convince the Supreme Court that school segregation was unconstitutional, but his legacy went far beyond that.

Joining us now is David Rosner, a former student and colleague of Kenneth Clark and author of the book ""Children, Race and Power: Kenneth and Mamie Clark's Northside Center,"" and he joins us from his office at Columbia University in New York, where he's a professor of history and public health.
Good of you to be with us today.
Thank you very much.
You studied with Professor Clark in the 1960s.
What did he bring to the civil rights movement?

Well, first of all, in the 1960s when I was a student, it was a very heady time for the civil rights movement, at least in 1964, and a lot of Northern white students thought of incredible opportunity, in some sense, improving American culture and society.

Kenneth Clark, of course, when he was at City College, where I was a student, was in some sense the luminary who we all looked to as someone who we saw really--the incredible intellectual who was, in some sense, at the base of understanding what segregation and racism had done not only to black children but also to white children as well.
So we all flocked to his classes because we saw in him, in some sense, the last best hope for American society and the hope for integration of that society in the mid-'60s.
Did--tell us a little bit about his research into racial discrimination and how it was received at the time.

Well, originally, he and his wife in 1939--actually, his wife, her master's thesis--when Mamie Clark, Mamie Phipps Clark, was a student, she did a very innovative study in which she looked at the ways children perceive themselves through looking at dolls and using dolls as objects of scorn or love.

And what she found, which was very disturbing and we're told to believe was expanded on by Kenneth Clark, was that children, black children particularly, tended to look down upon themselves and to, in some sense, have a lot of self-hate.
And that was shown by how they perceived black and white dolls, which black children often saw a black doll as ugly or not attractive, and a white doll as being very, very attractive and very nice.
So this was kind of breakthrough social psychology at the time.

And it ultimately ended up in the 1954 Supreme Court decision as kind of what was called the social science brief, the brief that showed that segregation, even though it was supposedly separate but equal, was actually harmful and very unequal, very damaging.
Kenneth Clark, of course, lived long after that Supreme Court decision that he played such an important part in, Brown vs. Board of Education.
Looking back on it, I wonder if he thought it accomplished what he thought it might.
Well, I think that's really the shock that I had when I was a student, when I took his class, because I expected him to be optimistic the same way that white students were at that time.
We had all essentially accepted the idea that racism was a Southern problem.

And at that point, in 1964, '65, when I was taking his class, he had already written ""Dark Ghetto,"" and he was seeing racism as a much more insidious and much more damaging issue, and especially an issue for Northern cities and Northern communities as well.
So he was not very sanguine at all.
In fact, he was, I think, pretty depressed at that point when he had realized how entrenched racism and the fight against integration would be not only in the South but also in the North.
This was called at the time a de facto segregation in practice, as opposed to de jure segregation in the South.
It's a pleasure to talk with you.
